title: SQLIN Keyword

metadata.description: Learn about SQLIN Keyword with clear explanations and practical examples.

content_sections.title: Details
content_sections.content:
Reference

❯
IN
The
IN
command allows you to specify 
multiple values in a WHERE clause.
The IN operator is a shorthand for multiple OR conditions.
The following SQL selects all customers that are located in "Germany", "France" and "UK":
Example
SELECT * FROM Customers
WHERE Country IN ('Germany', 'France', 'UK');

The following SQL selects all customers that are NOT located in "Germany", "France" or "UK":
Example
SELECT * FROM Customers
WHERE Country NOT IN ('Germany', 'France', 'UK');

The following SQL selects all customers that are from the same 
countries as the suppliers:
Example
SELECT * FROM Customers
WHERE Country IN (SELECT Country FROM Suppliers);

Reference

❯
★
+1

WHERE Country IN ('Germany', 'France', 'UK');

content_sections.title: Example
content_sections.code:

content_sections.title: Example
content_sections.code:
SELECT * FROM Customers
WHERE Country IN (SELECT Country FROM Suppliers);

summary: This tutorial covers SQLIN Keyword concepts and techniques. You'll learn how to use SQLIN Keyword effectively, including key principles, common patterns, and practical examples. By the end of this tutorial, you'll have a solid understanding of SQLIN Keyword and how to apply it in your projects.
